question: On screen. Absolutely. Mister Data, set a pursuit course. Maximum warp.
answer: We are approaching the Terran System, Captain.

question: Go to impulse. Where's the Borg ship?
answer: It has entered Earth orbit. Correction -- it is not in orbit. It is heading directly toward the surface.

question: Captain?
answer: In twenty-four hours, Zephram Cochrane is supposed to conduct the very first warp test... from a missile silo in Montana. If I'm right, the Borg were trying to change the course of human history by killing him or destroying his ship.

question: And if they succeed, humans won't make First Contact with the Vulcans tomorrow. As First Officer I should be the one beaming down...
answer: Normally, I would agree. But in this case, the mission requires a certain knowledge of 21st century history. You're many things, Number One, but you're not much of an historian.

question: Good luck, sir.
answer: I'll keep in contact. You have the Bridge.

question: Let's go.
answer: Go where? Hello? Is anyone going to tell me what we're doing here?

question: We're here to find Zephram Cochrane. He may be injured or dead.
answer: Cochrane... the inventor of warp drive?

question: Yes...
answer: But he's been dead for three hundred... Oh God... we've gone back in time again, haven't we?

question: I'm afraid so. If the Borg succeed in preventing First Contact with the Vulcans... Earth will remain in the Second Dark Age... an easy target when the Borg arrive in the 24th century.
answer: Well, why didn't you just say so in the first place?

question: Lieutenant Sandra Farrel. It appears death was caused by a plasma discharge. I'll note in her record that she never left her post. Did you know her?
answer: Not very well. We met shortly after the Enterprise-E was commissioned. I found her to be a most... promising officer.

question: Data... are you sure you're all right?
answer: I am still having difficulty integrating certain emotions into my programming. Grief, loss, remorse...

question: We still have to make reports on ten more crewmen killed in action. Maybe you should deactivate your emotion chip until we're done.
answer: No. Human beings do not have that luxury, and neither should I.

question: Picard to Enterprise. Enterprise, please respond.
answer: It could be the radiation, Captain. Try from the surface.

question: Mister La Forge, listen very carefully. If you remember your history... in less than twenty- four hours, a Vulcan ship will be passing through this system. When it does, this ship needs to be in space, flying at warp speed.
answer: I'd better get started.

question: It's not the radiation... and there's nothing wrong with the combadges... the Enterprise just isn't responding.
answer: Jean-Luc, this man needs medical attention, now.

question: As I recall, the town of Resurrection is about two kilometers East of here. They might have a hospital...
answer: What are we waiting for? Let's go.

question: It may not be that simple. This is an extremely difficult and paranoid time in human history.
answer: Are you saying they won't help us?

question: I'm saying they might shoot us on sight. You have to remember... these people have watched their entire way of life collapse around them.
answer: There must be some good people... even in this time.

question: How long has he been unconscious?
answer: At least four hours.

question: It looks like he has a cranial fracture, but I'll need X-rays to be sure. Get Ruby in here.
answer: He has a severe fracture of the left occipital plate. He's not hemorrhaging... but the radiation has damaged his KNA and his APR cell count...

question: Power. There hasn't been a lot of wind through here for the last couple of weeks. Most of the batteries are depleted.
answer: Don't you have any generators, or other fuel sources?

question: Maybe you'd like to take your patient to the hospital in Bozemen... it's only two hundred miles away.
answer: His automatic reflexes are fluctuating. We've got to get him on a respirator.

question: Bag him.
answer: Beverly -- your tricorder. Where's the battery room for the hospital?

question: I told you, there's no --
answer: Where?

question: Oh... just a little tinkering. How is he?
answer: He's stable... for now. But it would be better if we could contact... our friends.

question: Yes. But until then, you'll have to make do with what you've got.
answer: That'll be interesting.

question: Think you'll need that. It's no zone solution. You know. "No ozone."
answer: Oh... yes... ultraviolet protection. Thank you. Mister...?

question: Lieutenant, actually. Lieutenant Jonathan Scrimm. I'm the head of the Resurrection Protective Force. And you are?
answer: Jean-Luc Picard.

question: Great name. French?
answer: Yes.

question: You don't sound French.
answer: I was raised in England and here in the States. Thank you for the... no zone.

question: Where in the States?
answer: Oh... here and there. You know how it is.

question: Not really. I was born and raised right here. Never had much use for travel. Where are you from most recently?
answer: California. San Francisco.

question: Beautiful city. Used to be, anyway. I didn't think anyone still lived there.
answer: There's a few of us left.

question: That was a pretty clever trick you did with the hospital's batteries. How'd you do it?
answer: It wasn't a trick. I used to be an electrical engineer.

question: Huh. And what were you doing out at the missile silo?
answer: I'm an old friend of Cochrane's... I wanted to see how he was doing.

question: Lucky for him you came by when you did. He might be dead now.
answer: Yes.

question: Maybe you can tell me what he's been doing in that silo. We heard some explosions out there this morning...
answer: I think he was running a test on an old rocket engine... and one of the fuel cells burst.

question: You seem to have an answer for everything.
answer: Something wrong with that?

question: Not yet. Be sure you put that on. You need a lot of protection around here.
answer: Thank you. But I've never had much trouble protecting myself.

question: Worf to Bridge.
answer: Riker here.

question: There's a dampening field in place on this deck. Our tricorders are useless. Borg... Worf to Bridge. We're about to enter the Environmental Control Room.
answer: Any sign of Data, or the Borg themselves?

question: Negative. However, they've reconfigured the ODN network... and re-routed all power on this deck into Environmental Control. Stand by, Commander Where's Ensign Hawk?
answer: Worf? Is something wrong?

question: Something is very wrong, Commander. We're falling back. Fire at will! Fall back! Go, go, GO! Worf to Bridge -- force fields!
answer: What the hell happened down there, Worf?

question: Cochrane was going to use this solid rocket booster to lift the ship into orbit. Before the warp drive took over... everything would depend on these old chemical engines. Now here's the problem... This used to be the throttle valve assembly. It controls the thrust of the engines. It's been completely vaporized... and without it, there's no way to launch the ship.
answer: Can you reconstruct the throttle valve?

question: Yeah... if I knew what it looked like. There's probably five hundred ways to design a valve like this...
answer: We need to launch this ship in under eighteen hours... There must be some design schematics... blueprints...

question: We're tearing this place apart looking for them... but the computers are down, and the fires destroyed half the files...so far, nothing. If it was just part of the warp drive, I'd know what to do. But this... it's like trying to rebuild Orville Wright's airplane with canvass and sticks.
answer: Wait a minute...

question: Yeah, I looked at these already. You can almost see the throttle assembly in this one... but this guy walked in front of it when they took the picture.
answer: Could you reconstruct the throttle from a photograph like this... if that man wasn't blocking the view?

question: Maybe... Sure. Yeah. As long as I could get a clear look at the intake configuration. But so far, we haven't found any other photos.
answer: If there are other photographs... I think I may know how to find them.

question: Your resistance is... illogical. To us, your neural net is simply another piece of technology. We will learn its secrets.
answer: Who are you?

question: I am the Borg.
answer: That is a contradiction. The Borg act as a collective consciousness. There are no individuals.

question: I am the beginning... the end. I am the one who is many. I am the Borg.
answer: You are the guiding intelligence behind the Borg...?

question: You are the guiding intelligence behind the Borg...?
answer: Intelligence... ambition... desire... I bring order to chaos... It's unfortunate we will have to destroy you to obtain the information we need. You are a... unique lifeform. Synthetic... and yet far more than a simple automaton. You have no idea how close to perfection you are.

question: How do you define perfection?
answer: A blending of the organic and the synthetic. The highest form of life in the galaxy.

question: An interesting definition. But it is not one that applies to me. I am completely artificial. I have no organic components.
answer: Have you ever wondered what it's like to have flesh?

question: It is impossible to imagine sensations for which I have no frame of reference.
answer: That... can change.

question: What are you, an idiot? Didn't you see the red light was on?
answer: Ah... yes... but, I didn't realize that --

question: Thank God this plate was already fixed.
answer: Cochrane?

question: Yes... and I only had enough silver halide for one shot. So you're lucky you didn't screw it up.
answer: I'm very sorry.

question: Don't worry about it. Did you need something?
answer: Yes... I wanted to ask you about some photographs I saw out at the silo. There were three of them... printed on some kind of fabric.

question: Bed sheets. I used my last set of bed sheets to make those prints. Not the best material, but I haven't seen a clean piece of paper in five years.
answer: Did you take any other pictures of the rocket?

question: Sure. Why, did you want to buy them?
answer: Yes. I don't have any money right now, but I may be able to get some.

question: "Money." So you can get dome money...
answer: I can try.

question: You'd have to try real hard. No one's used currency in over ten years. What are you, from another planet?
answer: No... but sometimes I feel that way. What I meant was, I'd be willing to trade for the photographs.

question: Trade. Okay. The photographs... for a straight answer. Who are you? And how do you know Zephram?
answer: I'm an old friend... I met him when he was doing his undergraduate work at Cornell back in --

question: 'Fraid not.
answer: What?

question: You're lying.
answer: What makes you say that?

question: You're not someone who lies very easily... so it's obvious when you do... at least to me.
answer: Are you always sucha good judge of character?

question: Sure. It'll be ready by morning.
answer: Ruby... I need to talk to you about those photographs. It's very important.

question: I'm sure it is. But it'll have to wait until tomorrow.
answer: It can't wait until tomorrow...

question: You've taken your first step toward perfection. How does it feel?
answer: I do not know what you are referring to.

question: That's because you haven't been properly... stimulated yet. Do you know what this is, Data?
answer: It would appear that you are attempting to graft organic skin onto my endo-skeletal structure.

question: What a cold description... for such a beautiful gift. Was that good for you?
answer: It was... interesting. Do it again... please.

question: You should pay closer attention to those little red lights. You know, I'd be perfectly justified in shooting you right now.
answer: I'd say you already have.

question: Don't flatter yourself. I take pictures of a lot of junk. Okay, let's hear it. I'm sure you have a great explanation for why those rocket photos are so important you broke into my house.
answer: We're trying to repair Doctor Cochrane's ship. It's been damaged and --

question: We?
answer: Myself... and a few other friends of Zephram's.

question: Friends from Cornell...
answer: Some.

question: Lie. That's one. Keep going.
answer: A key piece of the ship has been destroyed... and our only hope to reconstruct it is if one of your photographs shows us what it looked like.

question: All right. Truth. I believe that one. Why is it so urgent you couldn't wait until morning?
answer: We have to launch his ship by tomorrow afternoon.

question: Or...?
answer: Or the shielding around the plutonium core will begin to deteriorate. Within a day, the entire silo will become so radioactive that no one will be able to come near it for a hundred years.

question: Lie. That's two. One more, and I pull the trigger.
answer: Why are you being so difficult? All I'm asking for is to look at one of the photographs. It'll take five minutes.

question: And all I'm asking for is the truth. That would take five minutes. For all I know, you caused the explosions at the silo... and now you're trying to steal Zephram's ship.
answer: I am not a thief...

question: No, you're a petty burglar and a liar... You're no friend of Zephram's. He is a great man. He's not like you or me or any of the other zombies walking around this town.
answer: No. He's a man with vision. He can see beyond the problems that surround us. He knows there's a better future out there for everyone... a future where crime, poverty and war are things of the past... a future where we reach out and seek our destiny in the stars. I believe in that future, too, Ruby. I believe in it in every fiber of my being. And I'm telling you... if we don't launch that warp ship tomorrow, there's a very good chance that future will never happen. You won't regret this.

question: Deflector dish... why the deflector dish...?
answer: It doesn't make sense. The deflector is only used for shielding and long range sensors...

question: Computer -- magnify grid twenty- one alpha.
answer: They're re-routing the deflector power conduits...

question: Computer -- thermal enhancement. They're connecting the conduits to subspace communications...
answer: They're converting the deflector dish into an antennae...

question: What kind of message?
answer: If it was me... I'd say "attack Earth now... in the 21st century... they'll be too strong in the 24th."

question: We have to stop them from sending that message.
answer: Agreed. Options?

question: Are we on schedule? The Vulcan ship will be here in less than two hours.
answer: It'll be tight, but we should make it.

question: What about our warp signature? It has to be strong enough for them to detect.
answer: I've enhanced the plasma injectors -- don't worry, they'll see it.

question: Let her in.
answer: Let me get this straight... you're from the future... I'm about to change history... and all I have to do is sit here and let you fly my ship?

question: That's right.
answer: And people say I'm crazy...

question: I assure you, Doctor, that after today... no one will ever call you that again.
answer: Just do me a favor... bring my ship back in one piece.

question: You actually performed surgery...?
answer: It was an experience. Metal scalpels... needle and thread... But I had a little help. Surgical transporter. I used it to beam out most of the bone fragments from his brain.

question: How did Doctor Almack react to that?
answer: He was so confused by what I was doing, I don't think he even noticed. Any word from the Enterprise?

question: Not yet.
answer: You think they're still up there?

question: If they're not... we'd better get used to living in Montana.
answer: That might not be so bad... at least for you.

question: What's that supposed to mean?
answer: I saw the way you looker at her... and I know that look.

question: Regardless of how I may feel about Ruby... our fates lie along different paths. Nothing can change that.
answer: You want some advice? Don't do this again. You know exactly what I mean.

question: Beverly, there were many reasons why you and I...
answer: I'd call them excuses. And the first excuse on both our lists was our "sense of duty." We convinced ourselves that it was more important than anything else. And you know what? It's not.

question: How do you feel?
answer: Different. My internal sensors tell me the ambient temperature in the room is ten point two degrees Celsius... But my skin tells me it is cold. My visual acuity has been reduced by seventy-eight percent... and I can no longer perceive light beyond the ultraviolet or the infrared... But I can see.

question: Until today... your emotions were trapped inside an artificial shell. You didn't know what it was to truly feel. And there's so much more for you to experience. I will guide you into a world of sensation unlike anything you can imagine. All you have to do... is give us access to your neural net.
answer: No. I will not betray my friends.

question: They're not your friends... they've held you back... kept you from your destiny...
answer: That is not true. They have tried to help me.

question: Have they given you what I have given you? Did they even try?
answer: I... do not want this...

question: You're becoming more human all the time, Data. Now you're learning how to lie.
answer: I wish to... go back to the way I was.

question: More lies. Have you ever know a woman? Do you know what it's like to feel her breath on your face... her skin against yours... flesh against flesh?
answer: My creator did not intend for me to experience these things.

question: Depressurize.
answer: Activate magnetic constrictors. Are you alright?

question: Just a little queasy...
answer: Try not to look at the stars... keep your eyes on the ship.

question: Right.
answer: And Commander, whatever you do... do not vomit in your exo-suit. It would be... unpleasant.

question: I'll keep that in mind. Over and under! Worf! I'm going to need at least five minutes!
answer: Understood!

question: ATR setting...
answer: Active.

question: Main bus...
answer: Ready.

question: Ready to make a little history?
answer: Always am.

question: Phoenix to control. Initiating five minute countdown... mark.
answer: We can't let her in... she'll see Cochrane isn't making the flight.

question: We can't leave her out there. When the ship launches... she'll be killed.
answer: Tell her to go back to Resurrection.

question: Captain --
answer: This is Picard. I've suspended the launch sequence.

question: Captain... we've got less than ten minutes before that Vulcan ship leaves the system. We've got to go now.
answer: It'll have to wait. Come on. Geordi, can you see into the room?

question: No... the door's too thick.
answer: Then we'll just have to assume it's still there...

question: What's still there?
answer: Get a tricorder. You're going to have to track my exact position in that room... What do you want?

question: There is no invasion...
answer: Wrong answer, Mister Picard. Try again.

question: All right. You want the truth... The Vulcans... are highly intelligent aliens. From another planet. Oh, I almost forgot... they have green blood and pointed ears.
answer: And you know all this... because you're a space-man too...

question: Solid rocket fuel at twenty-five thousand kilograms...
answer: Altitude fifty kilometers...

question: Entering the upper ionospere...
answer: There's a red light on the second intake valve.

question: A Borg in all but name.
answer: I am... grateful for what you have given me. But I still do not wish to be assimilated.

question: A universe of sensation is waiting for you... don't you want to explore it... with me?
answer: Yes...

question: Then take the final step... give me the Enterprise... and we can be together... always.
answer: No... I cannot.

question: I've deactivated the sensory inputs. That flesh on your body is just meat, now.
answer: No... no, please... you cannot...

question: You must give me what I want... now. Without the deflector dish, we can no longer send for an early invasion. We must assimilate Earth ourselves. I need this ship. Isn't it better like this...?
answer: Yes... but the Enterprise... my duty...

question: ... is to yourself. Don't make me hurt you again...
answer: No... no, it's so... empty... please... give it back... I need it...

question: And I need to control this ship. Let me into your mind.
answer: In order to access my neural net... you will need to create a positronic interface. I will tell you how.

question: Ready to deploy the warp nacelles.
answer: As they used to say... all systems are go.

question: The Vulcans should be out there right now. We need to break the warp barrier in the next five minutes if we're going to get their attention.
answer: Bring the warp core on-line. I'll lay in a heading.

question: The nacelles are charged... nuclear warhead standing by. We're ready to ignite the warp drive.
answer: Engage.

question: Warp field looks good... structural integrity holding...
answer: Speed... twenty thousand kilometers per second.

question: Hold that thought.
answer: Strong heart. Weak stomach.

question: Report!
answer: We've lost Bridge control!

question: Emergency override!
answer: Nothing.

question: I am re-routing Bridge command functions to this location.
answer: Eliminate their remaining defenses. I will send Borg to assimilate the rest of the crew.

question: There is a perimeter alert. A ship has entered sensor range.
answer: Vulcan?

question: No.
answer: Give me helm control.

question: Passing one-half light speed. The starboard nacelle's running a little hot...
answer: I'm on it... The inertial dampers are having trouble compensating... I don't think Cochrane built this thing for comfort.

question: Speed -- two hundred, seventy-five thousand kilometers per second.
answer: There's no temporal shielding in here! We're starting to pick up relativistic effects!

question: One minute to warp threshold...
answer: Captain, the Enterprise!

question: Picard to Enterprise. Picard to Enterprise -- do you read me? Their com system must still be down.
answer: Well, I feel a whole lot better with them out there. We may need some help.

question: I have repaired the weapons array. Phasers are on-line.
answer: The targeting lock isn't working.

question: I do not understand. The optical data network has been repaired, and all systems are functioning.
answer: Your diagnostics are in error. I need weapons.

question: The problem must lie in the interface between Starfleet and Borg technology. Your console may not be configured to handle the data flow.
answer: Can you configure it?

question: I believe so.
answer: Do it.

question: Mister La Forge... now I'd like to shake your hand.
answer: Captain's log, March 3rd, 2063. The voyage of the Phoenix was a success... again. And it appears the Vulcan ship has detected the warp signature and is now on its way to Earth. Doctor Cochrane... this is your moment.

question: My God... they're really from another world?
answer: That's right. And they're going to want to meet the man who flew that warp ship.

question: And that's supposed to be me...
answer: Zephram, you had the vision to build that ship when no one else on this planet could see beyond their own problems. You flew that ship... all I did was push a few buttons.

question: You're leaving, aren't you?
answer: I have to...

question: Where? And don't tell me San Francisco...
answer: No. It's a lot further than that.

question: It's the future, isn't it? Just like you told Scrimm. I knew you weren't from around here.
answer: No... I'm from France.

question: I don't care if you're from France or Venus... just take me with you.
answer: That's impossible.

question: Why?
answer: This may be hard for you to understand... but I'm duty-bound not to interfere with you, or anyone else here... any more than is absolutely necessary.

question: You've been interfering with my life ever since I met you. Don't stop now.
answer: Ruby... I'm sorry. But our fates lie along different paths. Picard to Enterprise. One to...

question: Ruby... I'm sorry. But our fates lie along different paths. Picard to Enterprise. One to...
answer: Riker here. Captain, we didn't get your whole transmission.

question: To hell with fate.
answer: Say again, Captain?

question: Enterprise. Two to beam up. How's Mister Data?
answer: He's in Sickbay. Doctor Crusher says he can be repaired... but we have to wait until we...

question: Return to our own time?
answer: Yes, sir.

question: Then make it so. Have you determined how to recreate the temporal vortex?
answer: Yes, sir. But Captain... are we... all going back?

question: Unless you'd like to stay.
answer: No, sir. Bridge to Engineering. Mister La Forge... initiate the temporal vortex.

question: No, no -- we'll have to rip out this entire bulkhead. We'll need new bracing members for the deck above and below. Data... You look good as new.
answer: You could say that I'm back to my old self.

question: That's great.
answer: Her remains... are they still here?

question: I'm sending them to the Daystrom Institute for analysis.
answer: I never realized how powerful an emotion temptation could be.

question: Temptation? You said in your report it was all a ruse... you were manipulating her.
answer: She was... a unique lifeform. In her own way... nearly perfect.
